author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: bobby k
content:
Most of my years in music have felt like groundwork-laying years. Just because your credits playlist isn’t looking the way you’d like doesn’t mean that growth wasn’t happening. I would challenge you to reflect on where you started 2025 and where you are now and take inventory of what growth or lessons you experienced. 

The most rewarding bits of this year for me wouldn’t make sense to post about. Paid off my first business loan. Improved the efficiency of signal flow in my studio. Learned to fix some gear. Stood up for myself in a hard conversation with some assholes trying to rip me off. Got out of the UAD ecosystem. 

None of that I’m posting about or adding to a playlist, but it feels just as essential (or more) to my business than the songs that got released.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So right on this, to a T. It applies to emails and communication too. @cian riordan  and I had a convo about this recently. I used to sign off master emails with “I’ll wait for your notes/let me know if you need anything” or some variant.  Creating exactly the situation @Rollmottle describes. Now I sign off with “let me know how it feels”. I use Samply for streaming masters and have every single feedback and waveform option disabled. The goal is to make it as much like streaming on Spotify or Tidal as possible. I do artwork or an artist pic, i do proper song titles and not file names etc

author: EliHeathMusic
content: Recently switched from Spotify to Tidal and I had the same reaction. I also can't overstate how nice it is to be able to easily access extended credits AND ALSO not know how many times something has been streamed. I hadn't realized this as much in the years that I used Spotify, but as soon as I switched off of it, it became immediately apparent how much seeing the streaming metrics as the first thing had been shaping my impression of every artist or song I listened to before I even pressed play. I think the fact that Spotify hides most credits and highlights stream counts is a subtle but very real reflection of the way that the company has been turning music from an art into a commodity.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Great discussion. Learning not to give a fuck about what people think is a necessary and valuable skill in life, no matter what your pursuit. Most people have zero idea what goes into any part of the music business (technically or monetarily) other than what they hear coming off a playlist, and it’s been my experience that it’s mostly idle curiosity and I’m happy to oblige because I like yakking about shit I’m passionate about. 

But also, you owe nobody anything. This is where trying not to care too much about what people think of you especially comes into play. Breaking the social contract, telling somebody they’re making you uncomfortable, refusing to engage in the conversation on their terms, etc are all cards you have every right to play. I’ve found a lot of power in vocalizing my honest feelings in situations like this. It is extremely disarming for people and can make things uncomfortable (real life Larry David moments), but being able to sit with and own your voice in those situations can be powerful (like Neo in the matrix).

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve got a good one of these: a girl I worked with came by to record a feature on a DJ Duo’s song. We spend a day or two recording it, and it’s AMAZING. I bring by everyone I know by the studio to play it for them, because I KNOW it’s a hit, and i want to be the guy who called his shot. I’ve got points on it, and possibly even a piece of the publishing. 

A few months later my little brother calls me and says “hey, I just heard *artist B* singing that song you played me that had *artist A* on it.

That song became one of the most played songs of that year, now nearing 3.5 billion streams on Spotify alone. My cut would have easily been in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not breaking a million.

¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 

Sometimes the stuff we do pans out. Sometimes it doesn’t. We kick Cian in the ribs and we move on.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Now I'm curious. How do y'all normally use Spotify? I've got a few modes:

1. I know exactly what I want to hear. I search it and start listening.

2. If I'm less picky I choose an album from an artist and listen through it entirely.

3. I put my *Liked Songs* playlist (roughly 2k songs, anything goes) on shuffle and let it rip.

4. Thurs at 9p I listen to my *Release Radar* playlist for the new releases from artists I follow.

5. Monday morning I listen to my *Discover Weekly* playlist and listen to the 30 songs it's recommending me.

Those are the main ways that I engage with the app. Is anyone here doing something significantly different? Radio stations maybe? Specific playlists?

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
I moved here 2 years ago with a bunch of savings and making very little money in music. It took me about a year to pull in enough income from mixing and spotify streams where I could stop living off savings and only on music income. 

But, It IS so expensive to live here, and I like to do things. typical night out is like $80 after drinks and ubers. Gas is $80. An egg sandwich is $16 lol. The constant worrying of if i was going to make enough that month got to me, so of a couple months ago, I returned to a freelance software engineering gig 3 days a week. Never been happier. A _lot_ of people in LA are doing the same: _side hustles are your friend_ . 

Another thing i'd add is when you first move here, try to combine your studio and living expenses. Studio spots here start at like $1800 a month and go up from there. I live in a beautiful house in silverlake with roommates where I have a room, my own bathroom, _and my own studio_ in the furnished garage for $1300. Try to get something like that.

author: frankieharper
content:
Thought for the end of the day… UK time 

Our arrangements and our mixes leap into existence from the womb of the metaphysical into a world rich in strict guidelines and predetermined boundaries. It’s drill, it NEEDS that thump… it’s lofi, it neeeeeds that blur, I want to get onto New Music Friday, it needs to be LoUd. 

Genre and playlists seem to rule with an iron fist… I often think that when an artist asks for a ‘brighter’ mix or an even MORE colossal 808. Not always… but often. 

Surely the overall and final sonic characteristic of our various musical expressions should be treated with as much emotional sensibility as our lyric or our narrative? 

Perhaps a dark lyric cries out for a dark mix… New Music Friday or otherwise?

Or is that built in?
 *wild generalisation hat firmly secured* 
Would it be too much of a reach to say that modern pop music is bright and loud because in recent history, pop music is high energy and bright in tone? Or is jazz historically observed from the back of a smoky leather bound room and so dark and dynamic just sits comfortably (whisky in hand) … I guess my question is… at risk of sounding a little Orwellian, do we control genre or does genre control us? Probably both? Asking for a friend.

author: Adam Thein

Damn.

So I just realized i've had Apple Music set to Dolby Atmos Automatic for god knows how long and it has been automatically detecting my audio interface as a multi-channel interface and turning on Atmos mixes for me that I've been listening to in stereo and they are 100% not the correct stereo mix. author: LAPhill
content:
Let's think about this from an activism point of view - are you actually trying to affect change, or is this personal? In the case of MWTM, if you write to them and say "Hey, I disagree with this and will be cancelling my subscription," they might notice. If 500 users do it, they certainly will. If they lose 5000 subscribers, maybe they'd rethink it.

If their user base isn't passionate about the issue, MWTM doesn't have any financial incentive to change what they're doing. Spotify and the other streamers have Chris Brown, and I can't imagine the amount of pushback they would need before pulling his catalog from their services.

As Noah said, everyone can vote with their wallet and decide where to focus their attention on a personal level.

author: Will Trotman
content: Not sure if anyone else had this experience, but I had literally never heard of Joshua Slone until the other day when everyone was posting about his album release. First of all, great record / artist. I checked out his Spotify and saw that he had no music out before this album. Correct me if I’m wrong but my understanding is that he got some tik tok traction then went on the road with Zach Bryan before any of his stuff was out? Was so stoked to see the amount of excitement around an artist’s first release (which is so sick that his first release was an album as well). This might be a hot take, but I think I’m a pretty big fan of the way tik tok has impacted music discovery. Obviously it’s not perfect or going to satisfy everyone, but it’s pretty awesome that all the doors are wide open. And I feel like I’ve noticed a bigger interest in songs, writing, lyrics, etc. From what I’ve heard, it sounds like people got to know some of these Joshua Slone songs well enough to be singing along at his live shows, and I would dare to attribute that to the fact that his lyrics are literally on the screen in his videos. Who knows, maybe that’s all bull shit lol, but wanted to throw it out there. Would love to hear y’all’s thoughts.

author: peterlabberton
content: Took this 100% from @cian riordan, but: separate output path for references! I send the mix out 1-2, references out 3-4, and any old mix passes/rough mixes out 5-6. They are all level matched and I can switch between them on my monitor controller. The level matching and real time switching right in front of me is key, to me. I resisted this for ages out of some misplaced sense of pride, but, dude, if you don’t have a good system for references... do it! I also have the outputs of my computer audio routed to record into the ref track via a pair of virtual channels in UAD Console, so I can pull something up on Tidal (!) and record it in directly.

author: Rob Domos

author: Slow Hand
content:
Mmhm. At first glance the obvious move seems to be that Spotify could double its subscription rate to $20/month and kick a larger margin towards the artist. I think unlimited music is certainly worth that. Setting aside, for the moment, all of the other complexities around market pricing, we also need to remember that Spotify's largest streaming competitors are Apple and Amazon.

These are companies with massive war-chests derived from the success of their non-streaming companies. Even if Spotify *wanted* to raise the cost of their service, companies like Apple and Amazon can afford to keep the price of streaming services depressed and sustain a loss on their streaming services for far longer than Spotify ever could. To my eyes, Spotify doesn't have a whole lot of wiggle-room to adjust their pricing and therefore their payout models.

I say as much, because in casual discussions around streaming payouts, there doesn't seem to be much awareness of the larger business ecosystem that a company like Spotify finds itself in.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man I’ve given this thing a lot of thought in my lifetime. Honestly over the last few years I’ve realized my biggest limitation is my taste. I can learn anything, or hire a person who already knows how to, but I have to have the vision. The hardest part is to think to do it. 

So we’re all informed by our taste, and we’re all chasing the sounds we love, and we’re all trying to make a living by finding where our tastes overlap with a broader audience. 

It’s not that we’re driven by dark playlist overlords, is that the search of overlap in our tastes finds us all in that domain. Does that make sense?

author: Deleted User
content:
Spotify was not even supposed to be a paid service… their model and vision was never having to pay for music again; and letting THAT be high quality experience as if you are playing records you bought. They did indeed do that, and I don’t think it will go back. 

It was decentralization they were after. the record industry was already beyond rescue (to go back to its heyday) so they wanted a better piratesbay where people can hear the music right away, and not the messed up mp3 that has been converted to different codecs multiple times. The platforms opening up to everybody is why someone like myself or my clients can upload any kind of music. 

I mention all of this to say… I think that’s what they wanted. But I think they were hoping more people would use the free version so they can juice more profit out of the ads. I don’t think they were expecting this many people to go premium, which lowers the value of each ads… (because they won’t be listened to as much)

author: Slow Hand
content:
That fracturing is also why you can watch a movie on HBO one month and then it leaves HBO and becomes exclusive to Netflix a few months later. 

If you're the license holder you can generate more value for your properties by limiting the licensing window and then re-licensing to another streaming provider for a more favorable rate. It would be frustrating to sign up for Spotify cause you love Led Zeppelin only to find that they've re-licensed with Tidal a few months later.

author: dylannash
content:
What are some of your favourite elements of your prod/mix templates? I currently have a separate production/writing template and then another for mixing but I’m trying to hybridise and streamline them a little more to get faster results and hopefully focus on the song. Also, most of the songs I mix tend to be one’s I’ve written and produced as well, so hoping to cut down on session set-up time.

Some of mine are an instant “duck bus”, which I picked up from Ian Kirkpatrick. It’s a pre-loaded aux with something like LFO Tool or shaper box on it, so you can quickly route and uniformly make things side chain.

Another quick workflow thing I love is having Pro Tools audio playlists with a bunch of reverse sweeps, impacts and other transition fx/ear candy hidden and ready to go in the session, so you can quickly try out a bunch. 

I also have the trim plugin added as the first and last plugin on every new track preset, as I use them to quickly manage the gain in and out of each track and so I don’t have to search for them constantly.

Ozone Spectral shaper on some music busses and as a replacement for Soothe on the mix bus has also been a real win (thanks Jon!) Although these sorta things aren’t turned on whilst writing as they have a ton of latency.

Keen to hear what you all find useful!

author: Eric Martin
content: I route my mix bus to a print bus and can use this as a ref A/B by toggling the input, then if I have a ruff mix or a ref I can choose the playlist of which one then I never process on a master, always mix bus process and print to the print bus, that way I can hear and SEE my mix getting printed in real-time as a check to make sure everything “looks” right as it sounds right

author: Eric Martin
content: all I know is it’s been around a lot longer and feels more accurate, AND Spotify/Apple/most normalization is RMS not LUFS, Apple has been normalizing since before LUFS was a thing and they use basically the same algorithms to do they’re normaling today that they used in 2001

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m pretty sure Spotify main normalization is set to -14 LUFS. 

In my experience with Broadcast, streaming, Advertisement audio, the LUFS standards have proven incredibly useful and quite reliable. Every project to do for “web” is mastered to -14LUFS, North American broadcast is -24, and Euro -23. Hulu, Roku, YouTube, etc all have their own little specifications for loudness. 

LUFS takes into account perceived loudness whereas RMS does not. It also does not measure or add to the loudness for passages of audio that fall below a certain level of loudness. So if something is far quieter, it doesn’t get factored into the average loudness.

There also, in casual discussions around streaming payouts, does not seem to be much of an understanding of how the value of a stream is derived and the affect of choices made by non-music interests on that derivation.

Choices such as using a pro-rata payout model vs a user centric payout model. Spotify has said they would adopt a user centric model if the general music community called for it. This would probably be better for most of us.

Or even nuance surrounding what the definition of a stream is and consideration for the type of record being streamed relative to the payout amount. A stream of a record of complete silence is worth the same as a stream of the largest scale commercial release.

author: Deleted User
content:
I only agree halfway. 

What does more value mean in art? How can you be more valuable than to make better music? All of that is vague. 
We all are working on being better, but not all of us are good. 

Those who aren’t good won’t make money- but I think those who are decent should make at least good part time income. 

How good you are is only quantifiable with stream counts. One stream count isn’t more valuable than the other. There isn’t really a straight parallel in what it means to be valuable. 

A song that saved someone’s life from suicide is a one stream count, a song that you didn’t know was playing while the phone was muted is also one stream count. they are both worth $.00437. I’m not saying a song that saved life should make more money. But was that more valuable than a song streamed while the phone was muted? Clearly it is

author: Will Melones
content: Shopify is so prohibitively expensive to use as a merch platform. Thanks for making merch sales suuuper accessible to indie artists, Spotify! 🖕

author: Will Melones
content:
I guess it depends heavily on scale. $40 a month just to keep the doors open sounds steep for an artist who isn't already selling merch at a consistent rate. I haven't looked at Shopify's print on demand pricing, but in general POD is much higher cost than bulk screen printing t-shirts (for example). So if you're a band selling at the scale where $40/mo. on a slow month isn't your *entire* profit margin, it seems like investing in a run of merch would pay for itself.

Now this is completely different if you look at it from the perspective of a clothing brand, where the goal is to have a diversity of designs available at all times, without the need for warehousing and a huge startup cost, and to consistently push sales to a customer base that's devoted to *the merch*. I can't imagine the vast majority of DistroKid artists are going that hard on ecommerce, but they could sure benefit from having their POD merch visible on their Spotify profile. The small artists I work with would probably be better off putting $40 into Instagram ads every month.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone here host their personal music collection in the cloud? I've got a massive collection that could get more love, so I figure I should look into a solution for engaging with it more often.

What I'm seeking is:
1) My entire 500gb collection hosted in the cloud
2) The ability to organize and catalog everything meticulously.
3) A desktop and phone app that will allow me to stream any of it at will. Like using Spotify on your phone.
4) Requires very little in the way of ongoing subscription costs.
5) (Edit) Ideally it would be open-sourced or robust enough that if the developer closes the tools will still function.

Does anyone know of any options that satisfy most of those needs?

author: AJ
content:
Today someone asked about releasing a full album on an artist website as a digital product. The caveat is that singles are released once a month for streaming (full thing on streaming platforms at the end of the year, so the example had 12 singles).  After seeing some good discussion about the idea, I'm curious as to what y'all think about it? 

The main points I've heard in favor of the move:
- 1 person buying the album for 10 bucks cancels out so many no's
- Prioritizes real fans over casual listeners
- Incentivizes an artist to make the album, because it's batching content for a year. 
- Forces the artist to view music as a business, but doesn't fully leave the Spotify ecosystem.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I keep my Spotify and Apple Music normalized, to live in the world most listeners do. And then Qobuz and Tidal are not normalized if a serious reference is required. Turning on and off in one app is likely to confuse IME

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Also remember that Spotify itself is a moving target - it can supply 3 different levels of normalization, 3 different file types (OGG/MP3/AAC) and multiple bit rates depending on settings/cellular bandwidth/mobile vs desktop vs embedded (car/smart tv)

author: Calvin Lauber
content: If you print your mix to a final stereo track, I will change the input of that track from whatever master bus output , to “MON L/R “ - which is the direct feed output of the Apollo. Then I mute that track and hit play on Apple Music (normalization off!) to print. I just record reference tracks straight in as part of the playlists of final mixes, that way when I’m in input mode I’m listening to my mix, and when I take it out I hear the reference. Instant A/B

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
I find it really interesting that for instance in music streaming there are various streaming platforms that pretty much do exactly the same thing (provide all, or most of recorded music at a cost). There might be slight discrepancies (spotify not having Joni Mitchell/Neil Young catalogue until recently) but they offer essentially exactly the same product so they have to convince consumers from a different perspective („we pay artists more, we sound better, we have spatial audio etc.“) 
And on the other end of the spectrum you have the complete shitshow that is streaming movies/series on demand where you have to have like 5 different subscriptions bankrupting you just so you can watch your favourite movies. It‘s interesting how those two offer basically the same thing (access to entertainment on demand) but have developed drastically different

I know we’re all desperate to get back into the Taylor of it all, so here’s my take as someone who has only heard a few songs off the album and is neither fan nor hater:

In an era where albums are getting shorter and shorter and listening habits are heavily single and playlist-focused, Taylor got a mainstream audience to engage with a 31-song, 2-hour project.

When you’re as big as her, there start to be fewer things you can do that are actually interesting and I think this is one of the most interesting things she could have done with her power, even if I don’t find the songs I’ve heard so far very interesting of in their own right

author: Zach Hughes
content:
A few extra caveats to add to the credits convo from yesterday. I just checked with my distributor and they do not allow for the delineation between 'producer' and 'co-producer' or 'additional production'. 'Producer' is the only option and multiple producers can be listed. I also checked Spotify and it is the same there too. 'Producer' is shown but no field for 'additional production'.

I agree with what others were alluding to in that it's worth considering how asking for revised credits impacts the relationship and that caution and being respectful towards and honoring the artist's story is valuable.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I was recently inspired after going to the cinema to see *A Complete Unkown*, the movie memoir about Bob Dylan; partially by Bob's story, but also by Timothy Chalomee's performance as Bob. All of the shots of him performing in the movie were fully live - which is an impressive feat by itself - but even more impressive that he apparently wasn't much of a musician before making the movie. I didnt know much about Timothy before this, so I watched his interview with Zane Lowe on Apple Music's YouTube channel. One thing I found really interesting was how available he made himself to learning the role. For example, he didn't turn his phone on for 3 months straight. Got me thinking about how much I can get distracted during the day, and how these distractions can get in the way of me actually giving 100% to the art that I'm working on. I'm sure you all can imagine how the distractions in your own life can effect your work. Might be TikTok videos, might be discord, might be lusting over getting new converters or monitors or guitars, etc, you get the idea. So I guess what I'm saying here is that if I want to compete with the best, maybe I have to understand how to impliment systems in my life that allows me to be more available to the things that I am working on. I want it to be like lifiting a heavy weight at the gym - at the bottom of a heavy squat, you've no choice but to focus on pushing the bar back up with good form, cos that think will break you otherwise. There's a certain thing that happens in your brain when you're forced to only think about one thing for a prolonged, or even short period. It's something akin to meditating. 

I guess what I'm asking is if anyone has ever given this subject any thought before, and if anyone has ever done anything to get better at these things? I'm still not sure if all this only makes sense inside my own head.

author: Dalliance
content: Also it’s pretty hard to find those people since there is no tool (that I know of) to filter through the inputs (musician, stream count, language, etc…). It’s easy to find mainstream artists of course but those are way above my shooting range

author: Dalliance
content:
Oh thank you. I could have collabs in my region but I didn’t want to base my initial success on riding somebody else’s fanbase. And my plan was never to keep within my region. 

No,  nothing English is out, only a few Spanish songs. But I wrote in a few songwriting camps, so language isn’t the barrier. It’s tough to breakthrough in here (anywhere tbh) in English without the help of a label (which I do not want), so imo joining forces and fan bases on an EP could work nicely since playlisting can help. A friend of mine, not a very good EDM producer manages to get to great numbers with submithub and hypeeddit, which only make sense in widely spread languages and Czech isn’t one of them

author: Dalliance
content:
Great perspective, love all of it. I'm coming from the idea that work isn't appreciated until it is actually heard, and playlisting is still a viable option to make that happen and English is a crucial element of that (public curator type of playlisting). Combined with another artist gives out higher chances.  
I'll definitely start swiping through socials and write down people I resonate with.

author: Will Trotman
content:
Interesting, that’s good to hear it’s gotten better, I was assuming it had gone the other way. 

I just wonder what kind of disruption could be large enough to cause a shift away from Spotify, since they’re pretty firmly on top. It seems like streaming is about as easy as it’s going to get, and I don’t really hear any Spotify users with qualms about their experience.

I do wonder if artists will become less partial to Spotify over time though. It seems like there are so many different metrics of success now (Spotify streams, instagram followers, tik tok followers are the main ones I think of) that aren’t always mutually inclusive of each other. And I wonder if that takes a little weight off of streaming numbers being the only metric that legitimizes an artist. And I hear people like Ryan Tedder talk about the importance of “world building” for artists now - I wonder if fans of artists will care more about being part of that artist’s ecosystem than the artist’s music being a part of their music library. I think of how K Pop bands sell crazy numbers of physical copies as an example. They can still stream the music but it seems like there are more variables now.

Thinking out loud a little bit, I might have just said absolutely nothing with a lot of words lol.
